I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  A transaction technical assistance (TA) for Supporting Public Sector Governance 
Reforms is proposed to support the implementation of the Post-Program Engagement 
Framework (PPEF) of the Azerbaijan: Improving Governance and Public Sector Efficiency 
Program (IGPSE) – Subprogram 2. This will help avoid any loss of reform momentum and 
support the Government of Azerbaijan in delivering on its commitment (reflected in the Loan 
Agreement for Subprogram 2) to deploy its best efforts to carry out the PPEF. Through this TA,1 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will be able to flexibly provide strategic policy advice to the 
government in the implementation of rules-based fiscal planning, in state-owned enterprises 
restructuring and strengthening of private sector participation, and in enhancing access to finance 
and improving the business environment to small and medium-sized enterprises. The reforms 
included in the PPEF and to be supported by the proposed TA are, in general, a natural sequence 
of the reform achievements under the IGPSE. 
  
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The policy dialogue process under subprogram 2 was successful in charting follow-up 
reform steps that will be crucial to achieve going forward and that can benefit from further ADB 
support. The ADB and the authorities agreed on a PPEF through which both parties can lock-in 
a working commitment to jointly prepare proposals for the next phase of associated reforms, i.e., 
reforms that are a natural sequence or necessary for subprogram 2 reforms to come to full fruition 
in terms of impact. As reflected in the new ADB Country Partnership Strategy for Azerbaijan 
(2019–2023), a second ADB programmatic assistance engagement is also being planned for 
2021–2022, and the expectation is that implementing the PPEF will help keep close policy 
dialogue engagement and the current reform momentum. The proposed TA is closely aligned with 
the  new  ADB  country  partnership  strategy  (2019–2023)  and  is  included  in  ADB’s  country 
operations business plan for Azerbaijan.2 It is also in line with ADB’s Strategy 2030, which 
prioritizes developing public sector and market institutions to support the development of the 
private  sector  and  enhance financial stability  (i.e.  operational  priority area  6 to  strengthen 
governance and institutional capacity). 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
3.  Policy Output Area 1: Implementation of Rules-based Fiscal Planning. The main 
implementing agency will be the Ministry of Finance (MOF). 
 
4.  Medium-Term  Expenditure  Framework  and  Medium-Term  Fiscal  Framework 
implementation. International experience offers guidance in this key reform area, showing that 
the introduction of these crucial multi-year fiscal planning mechanisms will now require a number 
of annual fiscal cycles of assisted implementation. The MOF, Ministry of Economy (MOE) and 
high-level coordination bodies will be crucial in monitoring implementation practices, and in

assisting line-ministries through such a fundamental change in the way budgetary and fiscal 
planning is done in Azerbaijan.3  
5.  Establishment of Fiscal Risk Management Functions. Azerbaijan does not currently 
have a formal institutional framework for fiscal risks management (FRM), nor any MOF internal 
stakeholder with any of the associated functions of FRM. This was highlighted during the IGPSE  
policy dialogue as a potentially very costly institutional gap. The implementation of context-
relevant aspects of an Integrated Fiscal Risk Management framework must be made a priority at 
this stage.4 Aside from key institutional design and development decisions, this also requires the 
acquiring of the necessary analytical capacity by several different stakeholders within MOF. The 
development of a roadmap to chart the possible multi-year sequence of steps and institutional 
efforts will be a crucial entry-point to this reform front. 
 
6.  Public Debt Management Strategy Implementation. The strategy approved in August 
2018 is a major achievement in terms of setting the stage for effective debt management 
development going forward in Azerbaijan. It brings about a more comprehensive approach to 
ensuring sustainable and sound management of public liabilities, and it is explicitly aimed at 
further strengthening the country’s financial sustainability, i.e. at meeting the financial needs of 
the government (by reducing costs and better managing risks) and upgrading oversight (and 
establishing “limiting”) mechanisms.5 The new strategy also includes explicit objectives on the 
development of a domestic debt securities market (which will crucially depend on a much higher 
reliance on market-based domestic resource mobilization in local currency), which is actually a 
pre-condition for the development of financial intermediation and access to finance in local 
currency in Azerbaijan. This is systemically important on its own. ADB TA will support the MOF 
and  the  Public  Debt  Management  Agency  in  implementing  this  strategy  going  forward,  in 
recognition of the crucial importance of its strict observance. The TA will also support the MOF in 
the development and issuance of internal regulations to govern and implement the restrictive 
stance (in the public debt management strategy) on the issuance of budgetary loans and state 
guarantees to state-owned enterprises (SOEs) (e.g. making proposals to establish a full-fledged 
conditionality framework)6 and financial institutions (to limit the use of such instruments). 
 
7.  Policy  Output  Area  2:  Further  State-owned  Enterprise  Restructuring  and 
Strengthening of Framework Private Sector Participation in Infrastructure. Output 2 will 
have  several  implementing  agencies:  MOF,  MOE  and  Small  and  Medium  Enterprises 
Development Authority (SMEDA)/KOB.  
 
                                                
3   MOF’s planning practices and analytical capacity for fiscal forecasting will remain a crucial enabler of success in this 
structural reform, especially with regards to the overall resource envelope, and must thus be developed further. 
Training to line-ministries will be important throughout, and this might require the development and implementation 
of structured and targeted training plan. The Ministry of Economy (MOE) could also be an implementing agency, in 
the extent to which the implementation of the MTEF depends on e.g. the issuance of guidelines and regulations for 
sector key performance indicators. 
4  This seems urgent not only with regards to the currently most relevant contingent exposures that the MOF must be 
able to identify and monitor (e.g. specific formal fiscal risks related to [state-owned enterprises] SOE exposures) but 
also in view of emerging potential exposures that near future developments might produce (e.g. public-private 
partnerships [PPPs]). 
5  A number of crucial elements referred to in the new strategy are e.g.: quantitative targets, to ensure sustainability of 
public debt; explicit ceilings on foreign currency and variable rate borrowing to minimize currently high exposures to 
these specific types of risks (currency risk and interest rate risk). Significant restrictions on the issuance of loans and 
state guarantees to SOEs and financial institutions are also to be established, etc. 
6  In line with the oversight mandate on this issue of the Special Committee chaired by the Deputy Prime Minister (and 
with MOF as Secretariat).

3 
8.  SOE reforms. It is crucial to continue to support the Government of Azerbaijan in 
strengthening the centralized financial management control of SOEs, while in tandem helping to 
deepen SOE sector-specific reforms. In the context of the latter, proposals will also aim to produce 
clarity on tariff and Government ownership policies. SOEs contribute 45% of gross domestic 
product and play a dominant role in the oil and gas, power generation and distribution, water 
supply and sanitation, railway, roads, air passenger, and communication sectors. Many SOEs are 
saddled  with  management  inefficiencies.  Further  corporatization  reforms  are  needed  to 
modernize SOE management and management control practices across these entities.7 It is 
critical at this stage that the reform path initiated in 2017 on improving centralized financial control 
and financial transparency of SOEs is sustained going forward with corporate governance and 
management practice upgrades, and with deeper efficiency-enhancing, sector-specific reforms.  
 
9.  Development of an effective Operational Framework for public-private partnerships. 
Building on the ongoing assistance to develop an effective, fiscally responsible and planning-
relevant public-private partnership (PPP) Policy/Program, and its setting of key future directions, 
it is crucial to establish the operational framework for PPPs and develop the gateway role of MOF 
for fiscal risk management of PPPs in order to enable the proper piloting of PPP projects. Right 
sequencing  is  key  in  this  regard.  ADB  can  continue  supporting  the  development  of  the 
government’s legal, regulatory and institutional frameworks and capacity for PPP development, 
to subsequently help develop an initial pipeline of projects to bring to market (as other multilateral 
development partners are also keen to assist with). A roadmap for this effort is crucial at this stage 
to ensure focus of reform efforts and consistency across all the parallel efforts deployed, and that 
the latter are properly sequenced. A cautious approach to PPPs in Azerbaijan is warranted. Best 
practice in jurisdictions with similar very low capacity and experience in PPPs has (and rightly so) 
been to (i) prioritize the completion of an effective and fully-formal operational framework, (ii) 
make policy choices that reflect a realistic assessment of the low initial capacity to develop and 
scrutinize transactions, and (iii) ensure the preparation of transactions ensures these are both 
bankable and fiscally-responsible.8 ADB can deploy TA to support these challenges, given its 
regional experience and its current and future involvement in Azerbaijan in crucial areas of reform 
(i.e. MTEF and public investment management, public debt management and FRM). 
 
10.  Policy Reform Output Area 3: Enhancing Access to Finance and Improving the 
Business Environment. Output 3 will have several implementing agencies: Financial Markets 
Supervisory  Authority  of  Azerbaijan  (FIMSA)  and  SME/KOB.  Support  to  Entrepreneurship 
Development Fund (EDF) and the Mortgage and Credit Guarantee Fund (MCGF) can also be 
made available. 
                                                
7  Many SOEs incur recurrent operational losses that are in large measure a result of ineffective sector and non-sectoral 
policy set-ups and decisions. By omission or commission, policy choices over the years have de-facto used SOEs 
as an instrument of specific economic and social policy, and this has not been the most effective instrument to 
achieve sustained outcomes. The consequent fiscal risks, and the periodic, ex-post, outright fiscal outlays that 
become necessary are still mostly provided in incentive-incompatible ways (i.e. not ex-ante nor contractualized, not 
performance-based, etc). This perpetuates corporate management decisions that are inefficient (and, ultimately, 
fiscally more costly). Sector-specific reforms are key to lifting financial performance and autonomy of the respective 
SOEs going forward in Azerbaijan. In sum, among the current key, legacy issues of SOEs, (i) high level of foreign 
debt and exchange rate vulnerability, (ii) dependency on cost-inefficient and performance-incompatible solutions of 
fiscal support, (iii) low accountability, transparency and reporting, (iv) fragmented and incomplete discharge of the 
ownership function by the government, and (v) lack of autonomous and capable utility regulators to govern tariffs. 
8  For example, in terms of concrete policy choices, many countries with low capacity but still higher experience in 
project finance than Azerbaijan have simply e.g. ruled out Unsolicited Proposals (USPs) from the initial decade of 
PPP efforts. Caution recommends that, at the very least, a moratorium on USPs could be in effect in countries like 
Azerbaijan until line ministries, the PPP Unit and MOF’s fiscal risk management functions build capacity to both (i) 
tender  traditional  PPP  procurement  projects  and  (ii)  properly  analyze  all  financial,  legal,  technical,  social, 
environmental and fiscal aspects of PPP projects.

4 
 
11.  Legal and Regulatory Reforms for Diversification and Access to Finance. In addition 
to reforms on credit information sharing, FIMSA has made important progress in establishing a 
comprehensive secured transactions framework. FIMSA is also embarking on a significant effort 
to further develop the legal and regulatory framework for more inclusive and broad-based credit 
markets in Azerbaijan. This path is well-known to be the only effective and sustainable way of 
addressing access to finance issues, and it must be sustained and supported. FIMSA-led reforms 
in this regard can sustainably reduce credit risk premiums in financial intermediation in Azerbaijan. 
The development of the legal, regulatory and informational underpinnings for financial and credit 
contracts is now a policy priority. A focused ADB TA project has been approved in December 
2018 to support a continuation of these efforts with non-bank reforms, and the proposed TA will 
complement this engagement.  
 
12.  SMEDA’s policy coordination and implementor role. The government is trying to 
promote SME development through the strengthening of EDF and the implementation of the 
operations of the recently established SME Development Agency (SEDA/KOB). The Strategic 
Roadmap on SME Development targets to increase the share of SMEs in the country's gross 
domestic product to 15% by 2020, and to 35% by 2025. The establishment of SMEDA, as a new 
policy setting body to (inter alia) promote policy consistency within this reform front and across a 
significant number of different government initiatives of direct funding, can be a path-breaking 
milestone in this context. ADB TA will be made available to support these objectives. 
 
13.  Direct Finance Support Initiatives. The further development of both the EDF and of 
credit guarantee instruments in the now-merged MCGF can also produce a major step forward in 
the promotion of market-based and sustainable access to finance. ADB TA can support sustaining 
these initiatives. Government of Azerbaijan allocated resources for the credit-guarantee facility 
under MCGF, and this initiative is now operating at confident underwriting monthly volumes after 
a lot of important preparation on both process design and pricing in 2018. This initiative introduces 
a price reduction effect between retail lenders and retail borrowers. This price reduction effect 
however can only be sustained and sustainable if it is rooted in effective risk pooling and 
diversification effects (like any insurance mechanism) and not lead to an actual depletion of the 
original resources allocated to its operation (e.g. if average pricing is lower than the inherent, ex-
post  cost,  of  risk  exposures  underwritten).  ADB  TA  could  support  ongoing  and  future 
implementation efforts to make these initiatives sustainable, and to ensure that additional fiscal 
burdens  are  avoided.  ADB  TA  can  also  provide  policy  recommendations  (and  support 
SMEDA/KOB in its policy-setting role) to ensure that the several parallel efforts of direct (credit 
lines) support to the economy (i) remain consistent with the ongoing efforts by the Central Bank 
of Azerbaijan to develop money-markets and the interest rate transmission mechanism in local 
currency (e.g. interest-rate benchmarks in local currency, etc), (ii) do not impede ongoing efforts 
to address the “legacy” problems of asset quality in the banking system in Azerbaijan, and (iii) do 
not disincentivize credit institutions from seeking market-based wholesale financing.9 
                                                
9 The latter is especially important in the face of eventual pressures from commercial and other non-commercial 
stakeholders to obtain additional fiscal support for their potential wholesale lending to credit institutions in Azerbaijan, 
i.e. effectively asking for a subsidy to their risk-taking on retail lenders. Such fiscal subsidy would take away incentives 
for banks to improve their capital adequacy and risk management practices and governance, and would also not be 
consistent with the thrust of the new Public Debt Management Strategy of Azerbaijan. These pressures are 
unfortunately a common occurrence in other banking systems (in other jurisdictions) that have gone through recent 
shocks to their asset quality. Many are now (i) in the midst of bank asset recovery and bank resolution efforts, and 
(ii) trying to rebuild confidence in the banking system. Experience has shown that stakeholders have often advocated 
(not always unsuccessfully) for the use of public sector administered funds (or the credit-enhancing capacity of the 
public sector’s balance-sheet) with the argument that there is no alternative. Unfortunately, all too often this ended

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $880,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, 
domestic transportation, provision of office space, and communication facilities for consultants. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA. The MOF will be the executing agency. The TA is expected 
to be implemented from December 2019 to March 2021. MOF, MOE, SMEDA/KOB and FIMSA 
will be the implementing agencies. ADB will engage consulting firms and individual consultants in 
accordance with ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and associated 
Staff Instructions. All disbursements under the TA will be made following ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The implementation arrangements 
are summarized in Table 1.

training activities, specialized entities may be engaged directly as firms.
